title: 103_s493
content: The "Hospital Cooperative Agreement Act" aims to promote collaboration among hospitals to reduce costs and enhance healthcare efficiency by avoiding unnecessary duplication of expensive medical services. Additionally, a Hospital Technology and Services Sharing Demonstration Program is introduced to facilitate this cooperation. The Secretary will establish a demonstration program awarding grants to hospitals for collaboration on expensive medical technology or services. Eligible applicants must be hospitals willing to enter into cooperative agreements with other hospitals in the same state or region. The Secretary requires hospitals to submit applications for voluntary cooperative agreements with other hospitals for sharing medical technology or services. The Administrator will develop evaluation guidelines for these applications. The Secretary mandates hospitals to submit applications for cooperative agreements with other hospitals to share medical technology or services. The Administrator will develop evaluation guidelines for these applications, and the Secretary will evaluate them based on specific criteria for enhancing care quality, preserving hospital facilities, and improving cost-effectiveness. The Secretary requires hospitals to apply for cooperative agreements with other hospitals to share medical technology or services. Grants awarded under this section must be used to facilitate collaboration among hospitals for enhancing care quality, preserving hospital facilities, improving cost-effectiveness, efficient resource utilization, and avoiding duplication. Amounts provided can cover expenses for specialized personnel, administrative services, support services, and instructional programs. Cooperative agreements facilitated under this section allow hospitals to share medical or high technology equipment and services. Not less than three grants must demonstrate how these agreements can improve access to or quality of care in rural areas. Rural areas are defined as those outside of metropolitan statistical areas. Cooperative agreements under this section enable hospitals to share medical technology and services, including drugs, devices, and procedures. Eligible services must have high capital or operating costs and help avoid excess capacity in the community. The demonstration program established under this section allows hospitals to share high-cost medical services for a term of 5 years. A report will be submitted after 5 years to assess cost containment, increased access to medical services, and improved healthcare quality. The Secretary will also provide recommendations for future cooperative agreements. The demonstration program allows hospitals to share high-cost medical services for 5 years. A report will assess cost containment, increased access to medical services, and improved healthcare quality. The Secretary will provide recommendations for future cooperative agreements. Additionally, it is not considered a violation of antitrust laws for hospitals to enter into cooperative agreements under this section. The Sherman Act, Federal Trade Commission Act, Clayton Act, and State antitrust laws are authorized to prohibit certain activities. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
